Without loss of generality, we assume a client can only connect to a single edge node. Table I lists the notations frequently used in this paper.

references: In the evaluation, we built a simulated MEC system for Federated Learning as a complete software package. The MEC system was established with simulated parties (i.e., the cloud, edge nodes and end devices) that comprise the three-layer architecture. On-device training in the FL process was implemented using the PyTorch framework. Each group of end devices (clients) are managed by and connected to an edge node via wireless channels, which forms a region, whilst the edge nodes and the cloud are connected through high-speed Ethernet. All the clients and their local network are implemented as being unreliable in the simulated MEC system. The drop-out probability of client kğ‘˜k is set as dâ€‹rkğ‘‘subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘˜dr_{k}, which follows a Gaussian distribution (see Table II) with its mean value set to ğ”¼â€‹[dâ€‹r]ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ‘‘ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{E}[dr]. For client kğ‘˜k, the relation between its no-abort probability Pksubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜P_{k} and its drop-out probability is: Pk=1âˆ’dâ€‹rksubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜1ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘˜P_{k}=1-dr_{k}.

We also implemented two existing protocols in recent literature: FedAvg [10] and HierFAVG [13]. FedAvg is the primitive FL protocol proposed by Google for the two-layer client/server architecture. HierFAVG is a three-layer FL protocol for Edge Computing systems and adopts a similar training architecture as our protocol by introducing the edge layer that performs the edge-level model aggregation before the global aggregation conducted by the cloud. HierFAVG has no adaptive control over the flow of models. Both the edge and the cloud have to await the responses from all the selected clients. We compare the FL training process driven by these protocols and our HybridFL under the same settings. The parameters in our experimental setting are listed in Table II.

Task 1: Aerofoil
Aerofoil is a numerical regression task. FL is performed to learn a global Fully-Connected Neural Network (FCN) model from a small group of clients that possess private aerofoil self-noise data111Airfoil Self-Noise Data Set, UCI. https://archive.ics.uci.edu/ml/datasets/Airfoil+Self-Noise. Clients hold different partitions of the data without overlapping and cannot share the data with each other. This task simulates an industrial scenario where the production data are privacy-sensitive. The size of local partitions follow the Gaussian distribution specified in Table II.

references: We ran the FL process in two ways: i) stop the process at a preset maximum round tmâ€‹aâ€‹xsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥t_{max}, and ii) stop when a preset accuracy is achieved for the global model. In Table III and Table IV, we present the results for task 1 and task 2, respectively, in terms of best model accuracy achieved, average round length (obtained when stopping at tmâ€‹aâ€‹xsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥t_{max}), the number of rounds needed and the total time duration (for achieving the desired model accuracy). We also investigated the model convergence by comparing the accuracy traces (Figs. 4 and 6) for FedAvg, HierFAVG and HybridFL. Figs. 5 and 7 show the average energy consumption by end devices.

We ran 600 FL rounds to compare the best accuracy achieved and the average length of a round. The results are shown in the â€Stop @tmâ€‹aâ€‹xsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥t_{max}â€ column of Table III. We can see that our protocol effectively shortens the average round length by 6% to 42% with slight improvements on the global modelâ€™s accuracy in most cases. In Fig. 4, we plot the trace of model accuracy over the FL process under the settings of Câˆˆ{0.1,0.3,0.5}ğ¶0.10.30.5C\in\{0.1,0.3,0.5\} and ğ”¼â€‹[dâ€‹r]âˆˆ{0.3,0.6}ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ‘‘ğ‘Ÿ0.30.6\mathbb{E}[dr]\in\{0.3,0.6\}. From the figure we can observe a solid improvement in model convergence by HybridFL, especially under unstable MEC circumstances where end devices drop out frequently. In the setting of ğ”¼â€‹[dâ€‹r]ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ‘‘ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{E}[dr]=0.6 and the selection proportion Cğ¶C=0.1 (Fig. 4(b)), the global model can hardly converge in 600 rounds using FedAvg or HierFAVG, but reached its optimum in 200 rounds under the control of our HybridFL protocol.

We also tested the protocols by specifying a target model accuracy as the stop criterion, and observed the number of rounds needed for convergence and the total time duration. The results are shown in the â€Stop @Accâ€ column of Table III. HybridFL requires much fewer rounds and less time to achieve the accuracy target in Task 1, which yields up to 4Ã—\times speed-up compared to FedAvg and HierFAVG. In the setting where the clients are mostly unreliable (i.e., ğ”¼â€‹[dâ€‹r]ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ‘‘ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{E}[dr]=0.6), HybridFL can still achieve very fast convergence, requiring only about 1/3 of the rounds needed by HierFAVG. Another benefit of fast convergence is energy conservation. Fig. 5 shows the energy consumption of end devices. We can see that our protocol is most energy consumption friendly to end devices. HybridFL reduces the average energy usage of end devices by roughly 50% for Task 1 in the case of ğ”¼â€‹[dâ€‹r]=0.6ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ‘‘ğ‘Ÿ0.6\mathbb{E}[dr]=0.6 and C=0.1ğ¶0.1C=0.1.

references: We ran the FL process in two ways: i) stop the process at a preset maximum round tmâ€‹aâ€‹xsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥t_{max}, and ii) stop when a preset accuracy is achieved for the global model. In Table III and Table IV, we present the results for task 1 and task 2, respectively, in terms of best model accuracy achieved, average round length (obtained when stopping at tmâ€‹aâ€‹xsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥t_{max}), the number of rounds needed and the total time duration (for achieving the desired model accuracy). We also investigated the model convergence by comparing the accuracy traces (Figs. 4 and 6) for FedAvg, HierFAVG and HybridFL. Figs. 5 and 7 show the average energy consumption by end devices.

We use the classic convolutional neural net LeNet-5 (consisting of two convolutional layers with max pooling and three fully connected layers) as the model for this image classification task. Again we ran FL for a fixed number of rounds first to observe the best accuracy and round length. The results are shown in the â€Stop @tmâ€‹aâ€‹xsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥t_{max}â€ column in Table IV, from which we can see that HybridFL outperformed FedAvg and HierFAVG in terms of the accuracy of the global model in all cases, especially when the participating devices are generally unreliable (ğ”¼â€‹[dâ€‹r]=0.6ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ‘‘ğ‘Ÿ0.6\mathbb{E}[dr]=0.6). Fig. 6 tracks the accuracy of the global model in the training process under the settings of Cğ¶C= 0.1, 0.3 and 0.5 and ğ”¼â€‹[dâ€‹r]ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ‘‘ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{E}[dr]= 0.3 and 0.6. It can be observed that the convergence of the global model is improved when using HybridFL as the controlling protocol. These results suggest that compared with FedAvg and HierFAVG, HybridFL can achieve the best global model in the fewest number of federated rounds.

We also compare the performance of HybridFL and the baseline protocols by specifying aâ€‹câ€‹cğ‘ğ‘ğ‘acc= 0.9 as the convergence target for the global model. The results are listed in the right part of Table IV. We can observe from the table that HybridFL significantly reduces the number of rounds and total time needed to achieve the accuracy target, compared with other two protocols. For example, HybridFL achieves a roughly 12Ã—\times speed-up in the case where ğ”¼â€‹[dâ€‹r]ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ‘‘ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{E}[dr]=0.6 and Cğ¶C=0.1, which represents a situation where the clients may drop out frequently and the participating fraction is restricted.
